;上周，有些时刻——如果不是为了第一次——唐纳德·特朗普似乎失控了。周一，在新罕布什尔州德里的一次集会上，他将自己比作纳尔逊·曼德拉；说他必须把国家从法西斯主义者、马克思主义者、共产党人和“病人”手中拯救出来；模仿了与乔·拜登的打斗场面（“噗！噗！噗！我直接打在他的假鼻子上！”）；并继续抱怨在华盛顿特区的街道上看到六个月前的麦当劳集装箱“从事房地产行业，”他说，“我总是保持房产干净，我喜欢干净、干净、经营良好，你知道，tippy-top，我们说tippy-top。我们希望他们保持尖尖的状态。好吧，我们的首都与tippy-top相反！两天后，法官阿瑟·恩戈伦 (Arthur Engoron) 拒绝在一桩民事案件中做出对他有利的中期判决，指控他存在欺诈行为，他跺着脚走出了纽约市的法庭。夸大了他的顶级房产的估值。在休息期间，他告诉记者，法官是一名党派人士，“他旁边坐着一个非常党派的人”。恩戈隆的职员坐在他旁边。在《Truth Social》节目中，特朗普将她描述为参议院多数党领袖查克·舒默的女朋友，这一点令人难以置信。那篇帖子导致了一项狭隘的禁言令。现在，在恩戈隆的要求下，特朗普声称他所提到的“非常有党派色彩”的人实际上是他的前经纪人迈克尔·科恩，他当天正在作证；恩戈隆告诉特朗普他不可信，并罚款他一万美元。这是特朗普在华盛顿特区、佛罗里达州、佐治亚州和纽约面临的四起刑事案件的不光彩和怪异的前奏——检方最近在这些案件中获得了他的同案被告的四项认罪。 （他否认有任何不当行为。）

;

;但特朗普在上周三的另一次法庭休息期间发表的评论表明，从一方面来看，他的控制力很强。 “昨天这个时候，没有人想到迈克，”他指的是路易斯安那州共和党众议员迈克·约翰逊。 “然后我们宣布了这一消息，现在他是众议院议长。”这是一个公平的说法。特朗普在许多问题上都存在妄想，但约翰逊奇怪的崛起表明他对自己对国会共和党人的控制力很清醒。

;

;共和党众议院核心小组过去似乎处于无政府状态。几个星期。 10 月 3 日，在众议员马特·盖茨 (Matt Gaetz) 策划的一场政变中，凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 被选为议长，表面上是因为他与民主党合作以保持政府开放；但这一策略可能只是盖茨表现出的自恋的产物。 （尽管盖茨否认了这一点，但这也可能是对即将进行的道德调查的反应，他将其描述为出于政治动机。）他似乎不知道谁可能取代麦卡锡——必须是一个彻底的特朗普主义者。< /p>;

;接下来是多数党领袖史蒂夫·斯卡利斯和司法委员会主席吉姆·乔丹之间的斗争，两人都属于特朗普阵营。斯卡利斯的职位更高，但显然他有一个敌人麦卡锡，原因与每个人的野心有关。乔丹在 2020 年大选后深入参与了特朗普保住权力的努力，特朗普对他表示认可，这有助于挫败斯卡利斯的竞选。然而，一些共和党人对乔丹犹豫不决。有人说他与 1 月 6 日的摇摆选区有点太相关，但真正的问题似乎是他大声的风格和他的盟友在游说选票时所采取的凶残手段。

;
;
;

;当乔丹被否决时，功能失调已经令人尴尬。国会在议长缺席的情况下无法推进任何立法，引起了国际社会的关注，使对乌克兰和以色列（以及加沙平民）的进一步援助变得不确定。问题在于，共和党的下一位候选人汤姆·埃默(Tom Emmer)虽然是特朗普的支持者，但却投票支持2020年大选。上周他试图通过在特朗普面前贬低自己来弥补这一点。在特朗普告诉记者埃默“昨天给我打电话并告诉我，‘我是你最大的粉丝’”后，埃默赶紧在 X 上发布了这段言论的视频，并补充道，“谢谢你，总统先生。”;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这不太好足够的。特朗普在《真相社会》上写道：“我相信他现在已经吸取了教训，因为他说自己一直支持特朗普，但谁能确定呢？他改变只是因为这就是获胜所需要的吗？”他将埃默斥为“全球主义者绿诺”。埃默在几个小时内就退学了。传达的信息是，仅仅向特朗普致敬是不够的，你必须真正感受到它。

;

;迈克·约翰逊似乎确实感受到了这一点。 2016年，他作为一名新生当选，并通过在从潜在的“穆斯林禁令”到第一次弹劾审判等问题上支持特朗普，在众议院站稳了脚跟，他是特朗普辩护团队的一员。他欣喜若狂地谈到总统回电，并登上了空军一号。他也参与了特朗普在 2020 年大选后的战略制定，约翰逊认为特朗普的战略是在自治领投票机的帮助下进行了操纵——这是一种彻底不可信的阴谋论。约翰逊召集了 125 名同事，签署了一份法庭之友陈述，该案由德克萨斯州提起，要求密歇根州、佐治亚州、宾夕法尼亚州和威斯康星州的选举人票无效。 （最高法院拒绝听取意见。）如果 2024 年选举存在争议，可以想象特朗普会如何坚持要求约翰逊使用议长木槌来帮助他。

;

;在竞选公职之前，约翰逊是一名律师为了保守的基督教事业，并写道他认为同性恋关系是不自然的。另一方面，他将气候危机视为自然现象，而不是主要归咎于人类活动。周四，他告诉肖恩·汉尼蒂，大规模枪击事件的问题“不是枪支”。据说，党愿意选举他，没有一票反对，因为他非常友好。但约翰逊的和蔼可亲只是乔丹的暴躁或盖茨的可怕的另一个版本：一种个人因素，在封闭的特朗普主义圈子内助长或解决争吵。

;

;尽管存在内讧的景象，但从某种意义上说，共和党在特朗普身后，很少有如此团结的情况。他可能是唯一让党团结在一起的人，尽管他给党注入了他自己的虚无主义烙印。议长竞选并不是他控制的唯一一场共和党竞选。集会当天，他正在新罕布什尔州，为该州的总统初选提交文件。在全国民意调查中，他仍然领先任何其他共和党候选人四十多分。 ♦

;珍妮特·温特森 (Jeanette Winterson) 于 1985 年出版了她的首部小说“ ;橙子不是唯一的水果;”，这是她童年时期的虚构“重述”一个工人阶级的五旬节家庭。温特森的父母收养了她，将她培养成一名传教士，一个她所敬畏的上帝的魅力代言人。了不起的温特森夫人殴打和斥责她，试图将她与除《圣经》以外的所有文化隔离开来，然后，在发现她的女儿与一个女人睡在一起后，在十六岁时将她赶出了家门。温特森一边学习 A-level 课程，一边担任殡葬师助理、冰淇淋车司机和一家精神病院的助手，以此维持生计。在牛津圣凯瑟琳学院获得英语学位后，她搬到了伦敦，在那里她从事了更多的零工。 （1997 年，她透露其中一项工作并不是性工作，确切地说，而是在酒店房间为已婚妇女提供服务；家庭主妇们用 Le Creuset 平底锅表达谢意。）

;

;“橙子”，其次是实验小说“;激情;”，1987 年，以及“;给樱桃性别;》让温特森成为文学名人，一个神经质、年轻的女性替代者 ;伊恩·麦克尤恩;和;马丁·艾米斯;。评论家称赞她烟火般的语言、她对欲望和情感的抒情关注、她的想象力和她的活力。记者 Angela Lambert ;写道;，实验性的早期书籍保持了“引人入胜的原创性的高标准，使用的文字使它们像阳光照射的大海中的海豚一​​样玩耍和闪烁。”但她对温特森“居高临下、甚至恐吓的语气”提出了异议，理由是“批评者很少……”。 。 。有时，温特森似乎没有能力应对自己的飞速崛起。她咆哮道：在深夜电视采访中，她宣称自己是;弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫;的天然继承人。当媒体要求她选择一本“年度最佳书籍”时，她选择了自己的书。当被问及她最喜欢的在世作家时，她给出了自己的名字。她告诉一家报纸，她的狂想小说“;写在身体上;”受到启发她自己与已婚经纪人的风流韵事——揭发了这名女子。评论家开始指责她内卷、自命不凡、自我陶醉。 “她无法抗拒小题大做的比喻，”《独立报》;声明;。 《旁观者》责备道，她的写作“本身就因她的自尊心和狭隘性而日益受到损害”。在;泰晤士报书评;中，威廉·H·普里查德;建议;“她最近的公开声明提出了一种可能性，就像现在完全褪色的伊迪丝·西特韦尔夫人（她为魔幻诗意现实主义做出了自己的贡献）一样，温特森女士可能会被证明属于更多的是宣传史而不是文学。”

;

;温特森从城市搬到了乡村。她聚集了她的朋友，包括犯罪作家露丝·伦德尔、文学经纪人菲利帕·布鲁斯特和演员维基·利科里什。她一直在写作——历史小说、莎士比亚的改编作品、对“;弗兰肯斯坦;”情节、儿童文学以及有关艺术和文化的文章。 “;The PowerBook;》将温特森的长期主题——语言、性别、通奸——与对互联网黎明的好奇融为一体。二十年后，她通过论文集“;12 字节：人工智能将如何改变我们的方式生活与爱;。”回想起来，温特森在 2011 年正式复出，出版了一本回忆录，回顾了她的童年，“;当你可以的时候为什么要快乐正常吗？;”，给读者;喜悦< /a>;.如果说《橘子》改变了她痛苦的成长经历，那么这本新书则一眨不眨地盯着它，对记录做出了更多的改变。温特森的最新著作“;Night Side of the River;，鬼故事集，及时出版万圣节。

;

;在 Zoom 上，自 2012 年以来一直在曼彻斯特大学教授创意写作的温特森出现在一个充满阳光和树叶的光辉广场中，原来是一扇窗户。她当时正在格洛斯特郡乡村的家里。她穿着一件雪白的系扣衬衫，上面的几颗纽扣潇洒地解开了。我发现她善良、慷慨、开放，而且非常有趣，对成为自己以外的任何人都缺乏兴趣，这令人耳目一新。我们的对话已经过压缩和编辑。

;

;;为什么是鬼故事？;

;
;
;

;两年前，Substack 这个平台要求我每周写一个故事，持续一个月，这很难。但他们的薪水很高，而且，因为他们想要我十一月，我说，“让我们从万圣节开始吧，好吗？让我们来做鬼吧。”而且，当我写它们时，我想，你知道，我真的很喜欢这个，也许我会把它写成一本合适的书。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;为短篇小说集选择主题的美妙之处在于，您可以获得非常令人愉悦的形状。对于较短的形式，因为没有时间进一步发展性格，所以你必须聪明地了解你可以提供的见解，以及显示人们是谁的小细节。这也是很好的纪律，因为短篇小说必须传达内容。他们需要一个开始、中间和结束。

;

;我想做的另一件事是将超自然与恐怖分开，因为最近所有这些都变得混为一谈。我最喜欢的鬼故事是“;圣诞颂歌;。”这个故事的欢乐、坦诚、慷慨、仁慈让我很高兴。我的意思是，作家注定要经历痛苦和痛苦，但不，你可以玩得很开心。狄更斯正在玩弄这样一个想法：一个鬼魂会代表你介入并阻止你在公共汽车下行走。这是一个非常诱人的想法，不是吗？

;

;;我喜欢这个系列的这一点。 《无鬼鬼故事》是一个甜蜜的故事，将鬼想象成一直在照顾我们的亲人。其他故事则更加哥特式，有邪恶的鬼魂和试图勒死你的衣服。还有一些令人毛骨悚然的未来故事，看起来几乎像是警告。 Was there a particular flavor of ghost story that you especially liked writing?;

;

;I was intrigued by what AI might do with our notions of being haunted, and I was playing around with the idea of the metaverse. If we did inhabit a credible digital space, an alternative, non-biological world where we went around as our avatars, we'd be starting to negotiate how to avoid the hard boundary of death, which is all humans really want to do. In the metaverse, there's no reason why you should die, if your loved ones wished to keep your digital twin going.

;
;
;

;In [the story] “Ghost in the Machine,” I wanted to play with the idea that you might start to have a real relationship with an entity that is a program but is much more interesting than anybody you know in your biological world. Where would that logically take you? It would logically take you toward your own death.

;

;;It was striking to me how AI converged with the ghostly in your stories, because to me they seem very different. Ghosts are aligned with the past, whereas AI feels related to the future.;

;

;I was brought up in a very religious house. Religion is so deeply sunk into the self for me that it cannot be separated. And so I'm intrigued that the religious notion of the biological self as a temporary condition is now finding a new home in science and tech. They're saying “Well, yeah, [the biological self] is a temporary condition that you'll be able to sidestep through the creation of a digital self.” That's the promise of technology, and it's also the promise of religion, the first disrupter of death. And it amuses me to see the separation from the biological self that religion has always promised and foretold coming into vogue, coming into fashion, through the agency of Big Tech.

;
;
;

;;Has your relationship to ghosts changed over time? Your upbringing was so devout.;

;

;Well, this is the trouble. Of course I believed in ghosts growing up because in my deeply religious household we expected to continue after death. But what was strange in our household was that I lived with two generations of traumatized adults. They wouldn't have called themselves that because nobody “in the war” ever did. It was only much later in life I realized that my grandparents and my parents had been in separate wars.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;They damaged one another. And of course they were going to pass on the damage to the next generation because no one talked about it except in a lighthearted way. But what was striking was that they and all of their friends, without exception, when I was a young person, all had stories from their separate wars about seeing or having seen something, seeing it very clearly, or feeling that they had been visited. And this was not for questioning. It was simply offered. My father's story was of being guided to the one house on the street where he could have safely spent the night during an air raid, the one house that wasn't bombed, and then finding out that the person who sent him there had died months earlier. My father was a very simple man. He could barely read because he left school at fourteen. He wasn't looked after or cared for as a human, but he was a good man. He wasn't a storyteller. This was just something he offered as one of his wartime experiences.

;

;;I appreciated the line in your book: “There is a valve, a pressure release, that comes with being able to say: 'I can't explain this.' ”;

;

;It's good for people in this world to say “I don't know. I don't know the answer.” When it comes to things that we can't explain, it's better to keep an open mind.

;

;During the pandemic, there was a resurgence of interest in the supernatural. It may have been because, for the first time, lots of people were quiet. They were receptive and open in a way that modern life doesn't allow. Everything is busy, noisy, brightly lit; people's days are managed. In the pandemic, perhaps you had that time to walk down a quiet road and not see anyone. That puts your mind into a different condition. And perhaps the mind needs to be in a different condition in order to receive certain things. If you're doing creative work, you have to move your mind out of its habitual executive function, its administrative mode, and to allow other things to come in, to allow patterns to emerge, to connect things in ways that are simply impossible when we're just formatting stuff.

;

;;My friend, when I told him I was interviewing you about ghosts, sent me an essay that differentiated between the aesthetics of the spooky and the scary. What do you make of that distinction?;

;

;I prefer the spooky. I want to disconnect the supernatural from where it is lodged in horror. ;Stephen King;'s great, but—I suppose we're always scared by what we can't understand and what we feel we have no weapons against. Because what do you do with something that's not a dimensional being? It can disappear at any moment. You can't grasp it and you can't follow it. You are passive in the encounter, and humans hate that. Maybe our ancestors were less frightened because they were more accustomed to the idea that there was a space where they did not have control. In a religious setting, for a religious person, you accept that you must surrender. You accept that there are limits to the human condition, and you accept the idea that you cannot know. You can't do ghosts by metrics. There's a parallel here with shape-shifting legends and fairy tales, where the genies can fit into tiny bottles or be three hundred feet tall. Once you get into the non-biological realm, the metrics don't work at all.

;
;
;

;;It really is like the Internet.;

;

;The parallels with the Internet are great! I love it that you'll be able to have an avatar, which is not necessarily human, not the same gender as you are, and that you can have a kind of playfulness, if they don't fuck it up and make it all about selling stuff—which they will.

;

;;I was struck by the number of queer and trans ghosts in the collection. It made me realize that my literary diet has been weirdly lacking in gay and gender-nonconforming ghosts.;

;

;Why?为什么？ Why should all ghosts be heterosexual?

;

;;I don't know!;

;

;They can't possibly follow the binary after death because it's a human construct. So that has to go. Ghosts appear as male or female because they need us to recognize them. That's why they wear clothes, I'm sure. It's for us, our limited senses, the narrow spectrum that we live in. Our senses are really crude: our auditory senses, our visual senses. We're very limited persons.

;

;;What is your personal relationship to the Internet like? Do you use social media?;

;

;I don't like social media, and I'm horrified at the way it's gone. But I wouldn't want a world without Google. I do think tech is neutral. We are in charge and it's a tool. All it's doing is showing us in this larger-than-life form our own grossness and inadequacy. Whenever we invent something incredible, we make it into a tool of oppression.

;
;
;

;The tech bros always get the words wrong. They say that the chatbots are “hallucinating” when they give the wrong answer to a query. The machines are not hallucinating. They're machine-splaining. Because they were created by men.

;

;;I wanted to ask you about ghosts and writing. Is there a connection?;

;

;I think you have to be open, to be receptive, in order to write. It's this business we were talking about earlier, how you get yourself into the right state of mind to allow new patterns to form, to allow new ideas to emerge, and to not start putting a formula on your work or trying to steer it in a particular direction—all the things that humans do. I'm always saying this to my students: stop trying to stamp it with an identity too soon. Let it be and let yourself be.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;People are frightened of not producing in this obsessed world of continuous work. And they think that it's better to produce something mediocre than to produce nothing. It takes time to learn whether you're just bottoming out or whether you need this time for things to emerge in a different way. It's hard in our world not to throttle your ideas to death.

;

;It's a large part of why I prefer to live in the country. There's no one around me here and at night it's completely dark. I am alone. I don't particularly like bright lights. In the evening, it's very meditative. You can read, you can think, you can let your mind settle into a better space.

;

;;You told the ;Guardian; in an ;interview;, “There is still that self-consciousness in women, that they are women, which is hampering. It's very difficult to do good work if you're self-conscious.” I wonder if self-consciousness has anything to do with the creative negotiations you're talking about.;

;

;I think it does. Women are always clearing up and tidying up and fixing it up for their families, for the men in their lives, for their bosses in the workplace. And, at the same time, women are always worrying about their appearance. The female subject now, thanks to the Internet—she's under relentless scrutiny on social media. It's horrible and very hard, I think, to be able to shut that out and just get on with your own self. To put that away and think, No, this is my time. I'm going to do my work in my own way. I'm not going to worry about any of that. There are hugely powerful assumptions about what a woman is, what a woman is for. It's like gravity keeping you in your place. If you don't have something with which to push back against those assumptions, then it's extremely difficult to have the kind of self-confidence that comes from being able to leave the self behind to some degree.

;

;;You've been a young, creative, rule-breaking person in the public eye. What was that like? Was self-consciousness an issue for you?;

;
;
;

;Well, look. If you're a woman who wants to do anything other than be an attractive doormat, you're going to break the rules. Any woman who wants to do something for herself is already in a transgressive state as far as society and certainly religion are concerned. So we start from there. Then, when you've crashed around and broken enough of the entry-level rules, you might as well start breaking a few more. You realize that all these things are propositional; they were invented and not by you and not really for your well-being.

;

;Yes, I was self-conscious. But there was no social media. There were only three TV channels. I live in England. Distractions were few. I was in a poor northern town. There was lots of time to think. I had the best life possible, I believe, for where I am now, in that it was intense, and it allowed a kind of dimensionality that wouldn't have been there otherwise. And it gave me—because I didn't feel I belonged, no adopted person ever does—a kind of resilience, and the determination to find out if I might belong somewhere or how I would make a world. Because clearly the one I was in was bonkers.

;

;Being adopted is like coming into the show after the curtain goes up, it's like starting the book after the first chapter. You always feel that there's something missing, and that you might as well write the story yourself because the story you've been given is so hopeless. That is a great driver forward. The most important thing that happened to me was a realization when I was sixteen that came out of nowhere as I was walking home one night from the library where I had to do all my reading because I couldn't take books home. And I thought, if I can read myself as fiction, as well as fact, then I can get out of here. Because I realized that I could rewrite it; it was as simple and as powerful as that. I thought, I don't have to be in their story. If I'm fiction, I can be my own character, which is why I became my own character in my first novel, “Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit.” It was such a mistake [for reviewers] to see that as an autobiography.事实并非如此。 It was me writing myself out of where I had been and writing myself into a place where I could be. That was the huge freedom of it. If we understand that our self-state is actually provisional, changeable, and propositional—that we make it up as we go along—we have much more flexibility and much more freedom than we think we do.

;

;;But then you went back, in 2011, and wrote an actual autobiography, “Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal?”;

;

;I discovered some information I hadn't had before, about my biological mother. I needed to revisit the material in the light of where I was then, twenty-seven years later. I didn't know where I was going with it. I simply set off. And after two weeks I'd written fifteen thousand words of “Why Be Happy,” which told me that there was enormous internal pressure to do this, a great geyser from inside. I didn't show it to anyone before I finished it. I had not expected to arrive there. That's why the last line of the book is “I have no idea what happens next.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;My core belief is that we don't know what happens next. But we can take control of our narrative, which isn't about the kind of me-first individualism that has so marred our civic or communal life and that I abhor. It's not about unthinking, unreflecting selfishness. It is about how you know your own story at a deep level and how you then proceed to tell it, whether or not you ever publish a book. Are you somebody who likes to play it for laughs? Somebody who wants the audience, who wants the approval, who needs to dramatize your life at every turn? Or can you find the urtext of who you are and be at least the co-author of that, while recognizing the other voices that made you as a younger person?

;

;And then the question becomes: What can you do? Can you treat your story as something that can be moved, that can be changed? I love working with texts and changing them, whether my own or other people's. That sense of liveliness that happens when the thing isn't fixed and it isn't final. It's so hideous, these ideas about the Bible or the Quran, that they are fixed and final texts. Fucking originalists. Give me a break. We're not where we were in 1787—is that when the US Constitution was written?

;

;;Nailed it.;

;
;
;

;It was great for the time, and we get the spirit of it. But what's more important, the spirit or the letter? If you're doing creative work, you already know that it's the spirit, the thing that must move through and continue to refresh itself as humanity does.

;

;;You're talking about writing for your life and about telling your own story as a kind of catharsis or liberation. But it strikes me that publishing your “corrected” version of yourself might be painful. You're giving the people you wished to convince an opportunity to push back or say that it wasn't like that.;

;

;Look, it's endless. One of the reasons that I've come to this place of peace, relative peace, after nearly forty years is because I have been through all the possible cycles of rejection, rage, hostility, denial, personal attacks, and just mean-mindedness. Everything that you can possibly get thrown at you as a writer, I have had thrown at me. Some of it was about my sexuality, my gender, my class. Some of it was about my attitude. It was very vicious for a long time. But anybody who stands up and says “This is how I'm going to tell it” is going to get hit. You have to accept that there will be disappointment and difficulty and that there will be misunderstanding. And it doesn't matter because hopefully, as you continue, you'll find that people have started to come to the work, different bits of it, and to find something for themselves to take away and use as a building block in their own work.

;

;;Do you have any opinions about trends in contemporary literature that you would like to share?;

;

;We've had an upsurge of women writing about their experience. This is an excellent thing. It's necessary, and it is to be appreciated and applauded.

;

;I find it quite boring. But that's only because I'm most interested in a kind of imaginative response to the world, rather than a verbatim response. When I was a young reader, I gravitated much more toward the European tradition than the Anglo-American. “;Invisible Cities;,” by ;Italo Calvino;, is one of my favorite books, just as I love those stories that fold into other stories, like “;The Arabian Nights;,” more than what we might call social realism or the new realism. But I am not here to sit in judgment. I want to embrace and encourage anybody out there who has a particular way that they need to work. We're too critical in the wrong ways. I have a rule with book reviewing that, if I can't find more to say about the book than some carping about what I don't like, I just send it back. Someone else will do a better job. The writer deserves better. And I'm probably missing the point.

;

;;That's very gracious of you.;

;

;Because I was messing around in the supernatural, and because ;Shirley Jackson; has had such a renaissance, and because I hadn't read very much apart from “;We Have Always Lived in the Castle;” and “;The Haunting of Hill House;,” I thought that I'd better go in there and have a look. I read it all and popped out the other side and I thought, This reëvaluation is not just. She is not very good. Then, lo and behold, I read ;Harold Bloom;, whom I kind of love, although he was maddening, and, bless him, he'd decided to go on the same odyssey and had come to the same conclusion. There were so many tantalizing possibilities in her. If only she'd been freer. Because some of the writing is gorgeous and she can't sustain it.

;
;
;

;When I do my courses with my students, I teach things that I don't particularly like or enjoy. I tell the kids “Read as widely as you can. Get as much inside you as you possibly can. Don't judge it too quickly. Learn why it interests you and why you get mad at something, why you get bored.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For example, ;Philip K. Dick; is a terrible writer, sentence by sentence. Something like that can be useful for students to see. We look at the sentence and we say, “Don't do that.” But then we look at the whole story and think, Yeah, but it works.

;

;That, too, is part of the creative process and part of what people have to offer. People come back up in time for a while and then they disappear into the waters again, into the darkness, because they're not relevant for a particular generation of readers, and then somebody else will find them. And that seems to me to be perfectly all right as well: that things should disappear, then return, be in vogue for a while, then off they go again.

;

;;I've read several interviews in which you describe yourself as “happy.” You've cast it in the past as something integral or defining about your temperament. It surprised me because I don't think of “happy” as a stable characteristic.;

;

;I'm an enthusiast. I'm not at all a cool girl. There are very many earnest young women at the moment, because young women who are creative feel that they need to be earnest. And all I would like to say is that you don't. You're allowed to make jokes. Men don't worry about being funny or serious. They think they're always serious even when they're being funny and at the same time they always think they're being funny when they're not. But, as usual, women separate themselves off from many possibilities in order to be taken seriously.

;

;As for happiness, I think the Americans were nearly right about it being a pursuit. But it's not quite a pursuit. It's more like an emergent property, like consciousness, and it comes out of a sense of meaning. For me, that's very important. I have to feel—and it may be my religious background—I have to feel, above all, that this is a life of service. You build the things in your life that matter. It's like having a 3-D printer. You build it layer by layer, and in the end you've got a rocket ship. It's incremental and you can make it out of mushroom fibre, if you'd like.

;

;So you do it layer by layer and you don't worry so much about where it's going to lead. With friendships, you go on putting the work in—you try to be a good friend, you try to show up, and then gradually you realize that you're building something that is both high and deep. That is very sustaining. It's these really quite old-fashioned core values that I think allow for a level of happiness such that even when things are difficult, as they must be in every life, even when we're struggling either existentially or in a practical way, we still have these things that we have built ourselves and that are solid. We can find genuine comfort there, which is not escapism or a delusion.

;

;Back to this business of rules, you don't have to play by anyone else's rules, but you do have to play by your own. And, when you've worked out what they are, just stick with them. Then you have self-respect, which is not the same as being self-conscious or self-involved. And that really does matter. Self-respect gives you boundaries about what you will and won't do. It also allows you to be generous, allows you to say yes as well as no. And it means that, even if you do something that in the short term makes you deeply unhappy or that you find deeply difficult, you know why you've done it—it might be getting out of a bad relationship or saying goodbye to a job that is actually destroying you.

;
;
;

;So often people imagine that when they make the right decision they will feel better. Ninety-nine times out of one hundred they will feel worse. When we do make these big changes, often it's really disorienting. There can be a rush of euphoria, and then it's hard, hard, hard. I think that's not often enough said. At that point, we can't look for happiness. We have to go back to the core values from which happiness will emerge again, in the fullness of time. ♦

;The only way to tell this story is to try to tell it truthfully and to know that you will fail.

;

;On the evening of Wednesday, October 18th, with the entire Middle East in a state of mourning and outrage, I took a taxi to the information offices of the Israel Defense Forces, a heavily guarded compound in northwest Tel Aviv. Like many reporters, I'd accepted an invitation to see video evidence of the worst massacre of Jews in generations, certainly in the history of Israel—Hamas's rampage through Kibbutz Kfar Aza, Kibbutz Be'eri, and other communities near the Gaza Strip, extending to an outdoor electronic-music festival, Nova. At last count, the attack throughout what Israelis call Otef Aza—“the Gaza envelope”—had claimed some fourteen hundred lives; thousands were wounded, and around two hundred and twenty people had been kidnapped and taken to the Gaza Strip. Hamas gave the operation a name, the Al-Aqsa Flood.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The roads in Israel were nearly as empty as they are on Yom Kippur.唯一可能让你放慢脚步的是警报声，警告说有一枚火箭正从加沙向北飞向特拉维夫和其他城市。这种情况一天发生多次。大家都知道的规定是，你把车停在路边，下车，平躺在路上，捂住头，等几分钟再继续前进。我到乡下还不到三个小时，就在 20 号高速公路的立交桥下等待。高速公路沿线常见的商业标志似乎一夜之间就发生了变化。没有零可乐，就没有丰田。现在，广告牌上高喊着团结的宣言——“团结一致，我们会赢”——并呼吁归还人质。他们的照片到处都是。当天早些时候，美国总统抵达会见以色列总理。 And, having delivered a message of ardent support flecked with notes of caution against being consumed with rage and making the kinds of catastrophic mistakes that the United States made in the wake of 9/11, the President was in the air again, headed back to Washington.

;

;The night before, in Tel Aviv at a friend's house for dinner, I received a series of WhatsApp messages from Mosab Abu Toha, a thirty-year-old poet who lives with his wife and children in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza.最近，他一直住在约一英里半外的贾巴利亚难民营的亲戚家中。他出生于加沙城的沙蒂难民营，四年前第一次离开加沙地带。他最终在雪城大学攻读诗歌美术硕士学位。现在，莫萨布用一句话爆料说，位于加沙市南部地区泽图恩的阿赫利阿拉伯医院遭到了以色列战机的轰炸：“上帝保佑我们。” He sent images—first of a burning building and a prostrate man, presumably dead, in the street—and he relayed reports of body counts:

;

;“Between 200 and 300 got killed.”

;

;Then: “More than 500 were killed in the hospital.”

;
;
;

;Then: “More than 800.”

;

;Then: “It's now 1,115 people killed in the bombing of the hospital in Gaza.”

;

;He was not claiming authority or proximity to the hospital but conveying the alarm on his own social networks.随后，莫萨布发来了一张医务人员戴着手套的手中抱着死去婴儿的照片。 “Sorry to send this,” he added as a caption, “but this is one victim in the hospital's massacre.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Soon everyone at the dinner table was getting push alerts—from Israeli media, from the wires, from CNN, the BBC, the ;Times;.谈话的声调非常高。当我们吃饭时，就像一夜又一夜一样，传来隆隆的回声：来自加沙的火箭弹。人们停下来，听了一会儿，然后继续吃饭。 These rockets, they had clearly judged, did not warrant a trip to the ;mamad;, the reinforced safe room downstairs.是否寻求庇护长期以来一直是一个专业知识和常规问题。后来，一些人离开餐桌，在以色列电视的 12 和 13 频道之间切换。新闻主播现在正在分享以色列政府消息来源的声明，否认以色列在医院附近的任何地方发射了导弹或投掷了炸弹；他们说，事实上，这场灾难的责任在于巴勒斯坦伊斯兰圣战组织，该组织规模比哈马斯小，但好战程度不亚于哈马斯。他们说，这是一次失败的火箭发射。 Hours later, American intelligence agencies declared that their information was in accord with the Israeli assessment.

;

;When I asked Mosab what he thought of the denials, he answered, “No one believes them.”他批评拜登总统暗示以色列不负有责任的声明是“不公平的”，并补充说，“好吧，如果是的话呢？” WhatsApp 消息让我的手机一直震动。 “它对过去发生的学校大屠杀负有责任，”莫萨布写道。 “What did the American Administration do in response?”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Like every Gazan his age, Mosab had lived through countless air assaults.有一天，当他八岁的时候，他出去买晚饭，抬头看到一架阿帕奇直升机冲向一座高层建筑。那是 2000 年第二次起义开始时。从那时起，他失去了朋友和亲人；他失去了家人和朋友。葬礼和瓦砾是他和邻居们生活的常态。 When he was sixteen, in the midst of what the Israelis called Operation Cast Lead, he was hit in the head, neck, and shoulder with shrapnel during a bombing.

;

;Mosab was not inclined to defer to the intelligence assessments of the Israelis, any more than Israeli officials were apt to accept discussions of the blockade of Gaza and the occupation of the West Bank as “context” for the massacres in the south.当然，有事实——其中许多是未知的——但叙述是第一位的，所有这些都充满了历史和反历史、不满和五十种愤怒，所有这些都以社交媒体的速度涌入。人们会相信他们需要相信的事情。因此，虽然以色列人和他们的盟友因伊斯兰圣战组织灾难性失火的情报报告而松了一口气，但巴勒斯坦人和大多数阿拉伯世界却没有感受到这一点。葬礼继续进行。以色列对加沙的轰炸愈演愈烈，造成数千人死亡，医院濒临倒塌，基础设施摇摇欲坠。以色列地面进攻的动员也是如此。 There were skirmishes between Israel and Hezbollah on Israel's border with Lebanon, threats from the ayatollahs in Iran, American warships in the eastern Mediterranean.

;

;The cab dropped me off at the IDF compound in Ramat Aviv.警卫亭里的一名士兵推开一个装有外卖通心粉的铝制容器，检查了我的护照，然后带我上了二楼。我走进一间宽敞的开放式房间，里面挤满了年轻军官和年轻士兵，他们聚精会神地用手机和笔记本电脑工作，向世界各地的媒体传达以色列的立场。一周以来，他们的首要任务是确保每个人都了解奥特夫·阿扎的暴行。现在的任务是公布有关医院爆炸事件的情报，同样重要的是抨击外国媒体，这些媒体早期的推送警报和头条新闻都指责以色列。 “在过去的十天里，我们不断被问及儿童是否被斩首，而不仅仅是被谋杀，”一名预备役军人、前总理亚伊尔·拉皮德的外交顾问亚伊尔·齐万告诉我。 “昨天，这些新闻媒体一刻也不犹豫地报道以色列对医院爆炸事件负有责任。 Where does that come from?”

;;

;I was led to a large, windowless conference room and took a seat.里面有三碗零食——花生、核桃和糖饼干——还有免费的以色列国防军笔记本。桌子对面坐着两个人：阿姆农·谢夫勒 (Amnon Shefler) 中校和以色列国防军高级发言人，以及弯腰坐在笔记本电脑前的马坦·哈雷尔·费什 (Mattan Harel-Fisch)，他通过闭路监控摄像头、GoPro 摄像机和手机收集了大屠杀的视频。哈马斯枪手用来记录他们所做事情的手机，以及哈马斯及其以色列受害者发布的社交媒体剪辑。他即将展示的合辑长达四十三分钟。但是，哈雷尔-费什说，素材无穷无尽：“我现在正在制作第二部电影。” The video would be shown on a flat-screen on the wall to my right.

;
;
;

;The officers were more than aware that they would be accused of propagandizing.他们并不太在意。 As Anshel Pfeffer, a columnist for ;Haaretz;, had written a few days before, what took place on the morning of the 7th was “the greatest massacre of any Jewish community in the historic Land of Israel since the Middle Ages.” Demands for vengeance were commonplace.

;
;
;

;And yet who would prevent another march of folly?总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡一直幻想自己是本国的丘吉尔，并在办公桌旁放置了一幅英国战时领导人的镶框肖像，旁边是现代犹太复国主义创始人西奥多·赫茨尔的肖像。在反对绥靖政策的演讲中，内塔尼亚胡引用了他的英雄的话“人类确实是不可教的”。但丘吉尔尽管有种种缺点，他并没有将一群救世主狂热分子带入内阁；他在受到刑事起诉时并没有领导一个国家； he did not leave the security of the state vulnerable to bulldozers and armed men on motorcycles.

;

;Netanyahu has been heckled by reservists and vilified in the press. ;The night flight from JFK to Ben Gurion Airport, six days earlier, was packed.在以色列航空公司的值机柜台上，即使在正常情况下，安检程序也很复杂，我后面的乘客是一位中年男子，他的手提箱上放着一把似乎是收缩包装的机枪。 I stopped worrying about the tube of toothpaste in my carry-on.

;

;“What is your business in Israel?” the security person asked.

;

;I landed in time for dinner with friends outside Tel Aviv on Friday.那天晚上晚些时候，来自卡法阿扎基布兹的三个孩子的父亲阿维猜·布罗杜奇 (Avichai Brodutch) 试图在特拉维夫南部父母的公寓里睡觉。布罗杜奇今年四十二岁，是一位极其谦虚的人，是一名菠萝种植者，后来转而学习护理。那天晚上，在黑暗的房间里，他盯着天花板。正如他第二天告诉我的那样，他的思绪“天旋地转”。他服用了半片 Klonopin。这对他没有好处。 His wife, Hagar, and his children—Ofri, Yuval, and Uriah—were hostages in the Gaza Strip.

;

;Early on the morning of October 7th, Hamas fighters swarmed the lush grounds of Kfar Aza.根据以色列国防军找到的文件，他们携带了准确的目标地图和详细的作战计划：“下属部队与保障部队一起前进。 。 。 。他们必须击落尽可能多的受害者，劫持人质，并使用各种汽车将其中一些人带到加沙地带。”经过大约两年的策划，由努赫巴人（Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades 的精锐部队）成员领导的武装分子冲破了加沙周围的边界围栏，其中超过 1500 人迅速冲向基布兹，摩托车、装有机枪的皮卡车。有些人乘坐滑翔伞越过边境围栏。穿过卡法阿扎的黄色大门后，他们挨家挨户地往窗户里看，试探着门。他们的步伐很有条理。为了将人们从安全室中熏出来，他们点燃了备用轮胎。为了防止逃跑，他们烧毁了汽车。 Then the real killing began.

;In the chaos, Brodutch lost contact with his family.几个小时后，他才得知他们失踪了。士兵们对散落在地面上的尸体进行了分类——其中许多尸体被烧焦并变黑。在大屠杀发生后的几天里，布罗杜奇被告知，他的妻子和孩子的尸体尚未被发现，并且一名目击者看到他们被带走，可能是在前往加沙的途中。布罗达奇回忆道，当听到这句话时，“我感觉自己中了彩票。” His family was alive.

;
;
;

;Now, in his sleeplessness, he needed to do something, anything, to make sure that his wife and children were not forgotten.他起身，洗了个澡，穿上了捐赠的衣服：短裤、T 恤和洞洞鞋。他带着他的狗罗德尼，一只巧克力棕色的脊背犬，开车前往特拉维夫，在卡普兰街的以色列国防军总部基里亚下车。自一月份以来，每周都有数万名以色列人聚集在这里，抗议内塔尼亚胡政府削弱最高法院权威的计划。 At around three, he sat down on a plastic chair next to a sign that he'd drawn reading “;HaMishpacha Sheli Be'aza;”: “My Family Is in Gaza.”布罗杜奇的兄弟从加拿大来访，贴出了一张他的照片并将其发送到他们的 WhatsApp 群组。白天，一小群人聚集在他周围。上午晚些时候，当我到达时，已经有数百人，其中许多人高呼口号，要求内塔尼亚胡辞职。 Another slogan was “;Hayom!; ” “Today!” As in, Bring the hostages back today.

;

;The victims of the Hamas attack—the dead, the survivors, the kidnapped—were not settlers or fanatics;他们主要是以色列的自由主义者，这个民族仍然谈论（带有警告和细微差别）和平和两国人民的两个国家。他们往往厌恶内塔尼亚胡，因为他的傲慢和腐败、对巴勒斯坦人的蔑视、削弱最高法院的企图，以及他与国家安全部长伊塔马尔·本-格维尔和财政部长贝扎雷尔等可怕的反动派结盟。斯莫特里奇。一些幸存者并不特别关心政治。有些人参加了之前的卡普兰街示威活动。他们加入了像“兄弟连”这样的团体，这些团体是反对内塔尼亚胡的预备役军人。 After October 7th, they put aside protest for rescue work.

;

;Brodutch sat down with me on a bench to talk, but every few minutes someone would come up and hug him, hard, shaking with grief and fury.人们不断给他送衣服、饮料、食物：库格尔、蒸粗麦粉、一堆肉丸。布罗杜奇既感动又尴尬，但即使心怀感激，他也吃不下饭。为了取悦一位访客，他吃了一茶匙石榴籽。 His smile was sheepish, his eyes full of hurt, though he could not manage to cry, much as he wanted to.

;

;“I don't know what my state of mind is,” he said. “有这么多的悲伤，有这么多的爱。”袭击发生前一天晚上，他的大孩子奥弗里在基布兹附近的一家餐馆庆祝了她的十岁生日。 “我们本来打算在周六吃生日蛋糕，”布罗杜奇告诉我。 “It's probably still in the fridge.”

;;

;A paratrooper named Ido Buhadana tapped Brodutch on the shoulder.布罗杜奇立刻认出了他。在他们的狂暴中，哈马斯武装分子不仅成功地蒙蔽了陆军的监视系统，并在二十多个地点冲破了四十英里长的边境围栏；他们还袭击了至少八个军事基地，杀死了数十名本来可以击退袭击的士兵。布哈达纳是当天抵达卡法阿扎的预备役军人之一，他们首先追捕剩余的恐怖分子，然后寻找幸存者。现在他也激动得浑身发抖。过了一会儿，他擦了擦头上的汗水和脸上的泪水，坐了下来。 “如果按比例来说，这比 9/11 更糟糕，”他说。 “The world should know how cruel these people are.”

;

;The scene outside the IDF headquarters was an open-air shiva, part of a ;national; shiva.如此多的祝福者涌向布罗杜奇，他最终要求休息一下，然后和他的兄弟一起出发了。不久之后，当我们再次见面时，布罗杜奇明确表示，他想传达一个与当时主流情绪不相符的信息——对复仇的渴望，对以色列政府未能保护以色列的愤怒。它的公民。布罗杜奇承认国家失败了：“这是一场巨大的灾难，将在未来几年内进行调查。”但他对绑架他家人的人的评论是经过深思熟虑的。他的妻子和孩子都在哈马斯手中，哈马斯敏锐地意识到国外（包括以色列）有关该组织的文字和言论。每次以色列投下炸弹，他都担心这可能会杀死他的家人。 “我必须希望有人照顾他们，”他说。 “哈马斯的杀戮太过分了。我不认为他们认为事情会发展到那么远。至少，我愿意相信这一点。他们的宗教信仰是和平的。 No religion can be successful for long if it is not peaceful.”

;He was terrified by the prospect of a ground war. “我们走错了路，”他说。 “我们得到了上帝的征兆，如果我们将其解读为发动战争的征兆，那是一回事。我们应该向妇女、儿童和老人提供人道主义援助。哈马斯认为妇女、儿童和老人不应该受到攻击，但他们这边却出了大问题。 I don't think they thought this attack would be so easy, and they just ;lost; it.”

;

;Uriah, his youngest, is four and a half.布罗杜奇说，他想象他的儿子“无论在哪里都会造成严重破坏”，也许正是因为这个原因，哈马斯才会失去耐心，让他成为第一个被释放的人。 “I've seen military conflict for years and years,” he said, “and it solves nothing.”

;

;On a trip to Gaza during the second intifada, I met one of the founders of Hamas, a former surgeon named Mahmoud al-Zahar.那是 2001 年，扎哈尔五十七岁。 “‘大卫’，”他说。 “这是一个犹太名字，不是吗？”哈马斯是巴勒斯坦解放组织的激进宗教对手，决心解放“整个巴勒斯坦”。 Hamas might consider a two-state solution, but only as a ;hudna;, a ceasefire.扎哈尔说，最终目标“是在巴勒斯坦、埃及、黎巴嫩、沙特阿拉伯——所有地方都在一个哈里发统治下建立一个伊斯兰国家。” Certain conclusions followed from this: “We will not tolerate a non-Islamic state on Islamic lands.”

;The spiritual leader of Hamas, an outgrowth of the Muslim Brotherhood, was a Gazan sheikh named Ahmed Yassin, who, in the years after the 1967 Six-Day War, established a range of social-service organizations in Gaza, which had just become Israeli-occupied territory.那时，许多以色列人在加沙城购物或去附近的海滩；数以万计的加沙人定期在以色列境内工作，亚辛担心这种做法会腐蚀年轻穆斯林的道德价值观。 He stressed ;da'wa,; the call to God.但是，为了将武装分子控制在自己的范围内，并与巴解组织作为抵抗力量保持同步，亚辛批准进口武器和组建新生的民兵组织。 1987 年，当第一次起义开始时，哈马斯（Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiyya，伊斯兰抵抗运动的缩写）在加沙难民营诞生。四年后，哈马斯成立了自己的军事分支“伊兹丁卡萨姆旅”。今天，该旅由出生于加沙南部汗尤尼斯难民营的穆罕默德·德伊夫领导，这些年来，该旅支持了无数针对以色列的军事行动，从汽车炸弹到自杀式袭击，尽管从未有过如此复杂的战术或如此复杂的行动。雄心勃勃的阿克萨洪水行动。 Among the stated objectives of the massacre, a Hamas leader said, was to free Palestinian prisoners in Israel and to protect the Al-Aqsa Mosque from desecration, but many suspected ambitions that were wider in scope, including scuttling a rapprochement between Israel and Saudi Arabia.

;

;The original Hamas charter, or covenant, was a nine-thousand-word treatise adopted shortly after the group's founding.它充满了反犹太主义阴谋论，以及所有关于狡猾、贪婪和统治世界的传统比喻：它声称，犹太人发动了第一次世界大战，其目的是推翻伊斯兰哈里发国，而他们发动第二次世界大战是为了“从战争物资贸易中获取巨额利润”。 The Zionists, who had replaced “the state of truth” with “the state of evil,” aspire to “expand from the Nile to the Euphrates,” while Hamas “strives to raise the banner of Allah over every inch of Palestine.”

;

;Hamas, in its first decade, established no caliphate, but it did help propel the ascent of the right in Israeli politics.以色列和巴解组织于 1993 年在华盛顿签署奥斯陆协议后； 1994 年在开罗； 1995 年，在埃及塔巴，哈马斯试图破坏具有约束力的两国解决方案的进展。该组织谴责巴解组织承认以色列国，并支持在耶路撒冷、特拉维夫和其他地方发生一系列自杀式爆炸事件。以色列武装分子也试图破坏这些协议，1995 年，一名年轻的右翼狂热分子暗杀了总理伊扎克·拉宾 (Yitzhak Rabin)。以色列选民起初似乎可能会转向拉宾工党候选人西蒙·佩雷斯，他与拉宾和亚西尔·阿拉法特一起获得了诺贝尔和平奖，因为他在构思奥斯陆协议方面发挥了作用。从某种意义上说，哈马斯是破坏者。内塔尼亚胡和他的利库德集团利用人民的恐惧，在保守派、定居者、极端正统派以及起源于中东和北非的犹太人米兹拉奇的支持下获胜。在竞选期间，当他告诉塞法迪人的精神领袖拉比伊扎克·卡杜里（Yitzhak Kaduri）时，“左派分子已经忘记了犹太人是什么。他们认为他们会将安全交给阿拉伯人——阿拉伯人会照顾我们。” He won the election, and though he has spent occasional periods in the wilderness, he has now been Prime Minister for a total of sixteen years, longer even than David Ben-Gurion.

;

;In Netanyahu's first term, I spoke at length with him in Jerusalem, and even interviewed his father, Benzion, a reclusive scholar of the Spanish Inquisition whose sense that Jewish history is in perpetual danger of coming to an end exerted a powerful influence on his son. “犹太人民的历史与其他民族不同，因为他们缺乏民族生存的要素，”总理告诉我。 “另一方面，他们并没有完全灭亡。 They perished ;mostly;.在基督诞生时，他们大约占罗马帝国的百分之十，所以无论如何计算，他们应该是大约一亿两千万，而不是一千二百万。 。 。 。在我们历史上最严重的灾难之后发生的事情是，我们以某种方式聚集了全国意愿，在以色列重建犹太人生活的重要中心。”内塔尼亚胡对国家和他自己作为不抱幻想的守护者的认识是明确的：“你必须保护自己。这是犹太人所没有的。他们没有办法保护自己免受邪恶和人类卑鄙冲动的侵害。他们付出了与其他人不同的代价。 We now have the means to protect ourselves.”

;

;In 2005, Ariel Sharon, a Likud Prime Minister known as the Bulldozer, defied much of his right-wing constituency by evacuating the Israeli settlements in Gaza.脱离接触的目的是实现大致和平并让以色列更加安全，但次年哈马斯上台，赢得立法选举，并在军事对抗后将巴勒斯坦权力机构赶出加沙地带。 There have been no elections since.

;;

;Although the occupation had, in the Israeli view, ended, Gaza remained under siege and blockade, and a spiral of violence deepened the immiseration of daily life. 2008 年 12 月，经过一段时间的卡萨姆火箭弹和反袭击后，以色列发起了铸铅行动，造成至少 1000 名巴勒斯坦人死亡，加沙城的市政基础设施遭到破坏，数千人无家可归。 2012年，以色列对哈马斯的火箭弹袭击进行了为期八天的空袭；至少八十七名巴勒斯坦平民被杀。 In 2014, after Hamas abducted and murdered three Israeli teen-agers, Israel commenced a seven-week assault, killing more than fourteen hundred Palestinian civilians.

;In 2017, Hamas toned down its rhetoric.尽管哈马斯在加沙地带实行独裁统治，镇压巴勒斯坦权力机构和任何其他权力竞争对手，但该组织在其最新宣言第 28 条中声称，“哈马斯相信并坚持在多元化的基础上管理其巴勒斯坦关系” 、民主、国家伙伴关系、接受对方以及采取对话。” The new document said that Hamas's fight was with Zionism, not with the Jewish people as such, but it unhesitatingly reaffirmed its ultimate ambition of eliminating the “Zionist entity.”

;

;As the Israeli right solidified its hold on power, some in the country came to view its draconian anti-Palestinian policies with repugnance.亚伊尔·戈兰 (Yair Golan) 是一名六十出头的退役陆军将军。他的头发已经花白，但身材却像刀片一样瘦削。他在第二次起义期间担任步兵指挥官，然后在约旦河西岸领导朱迪亚和撒玛利亚师。但他对军方对待巴勒斯坦人的方式越来越反感，而且他也没有隐瞒自己的观点。七年前，他在特尔伊扎克基布兹举行的大屠杀纪念日仪式上发表的演讲引起了轩然大波。时任以色列国防军副参谋长的戈兰警告说，以色列社会对“对方”已经变得冷酷无情，他说：“如果说在大屠杀的记忆中有什么让我感到害怕的话，那就是确定可怕的过程七十、八十、九十年前发生在欧洲，特别是德国，并在今天，即 2016 年，找到了它们存在的证据。”他提到在希伯伦发生的一起事件，一名以色列国防军中士被拍摄到射杀一名巴勒斯坦人，这名巴勒斯坦人刺伤了一名以色列士兵，但该士兵已经被制服并倒地。 “There is nothing easier and simpler,” Golan said, “than behaving like a beast, becoming morally corrupt, and sanctimonious.”

;

;Although Isaac Herzog, now Israel's President, praised Golan for his “morality and responsibility,” Netanyahu blasted Golan's reference to the Holocaust as “outrageous,” and there were countless calls for the general's resignation. In the end, he walked back his comments somewhat, but his disenchantment was such that he joined Meretz, a political party to the left of Labor, vowing to battle the annexation of the West Bank.

;

;I ran into Golan at the studios of Channel 13, near Jerusalem.他在那里讲述了他在大屠杀当天早上所做的事情。作为一名预备役军人，他穿上制服，拿起枪，开车前往拉姆勒市的一个军事前哨，并要求成为一名“特使”。他一路向南，开始接到朋友或家人在该地区的电话，其中一些人正在雷伊姆的新星节。 The calls came first from his sister and from a reporter at ;Haaretz;—both of whom had relatives hiding from the attackers—and then from others.他把他们全部救了出来，把他们从灌木丛和树木后面拉出来，送到安全的地方。 Suddenly, he was all over the news.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;

;

;As we sat together, Golan talked about the depths of the Israeli failure.关于那些认为通过“缩小冲突”可以无限期维持现状的官员。关于高围栏和过度依赖“初创国家”技术和特种部队的安全系统所产生的自满情绪。关于内塔尼亚胡及其情报和军事官僚机构未能注意到加沙及其他地区迫在眉睫的危险的警告。关于政府的道德缺陷，一心想要保护总理免受刑事起诉，而对封锁加沙和占领约旦河西岸的腐蚀性影响漠不关心。 All these factors helped open the way to the October 7th massacre, he believed, and to a war being led by an untrustworthy leader.

;
;
;

;“When you have a crisis, like Pearl Harbor or September 11th, it is a multidimensional crisis, a multidimensional failure,” Golan said.内塔尼亚胡在铸铅行动后于 2009 年第二次当选，“犯了一个可怕的战略错误，”戈兰继续说道。 “他想要安静。因此，虽然哈马斯相对安静，但内塔尼亚胡认为没有必要对更大的巴勒斯坦问题抱有愿景。由于他需要定居者和极端正统派的支持，他安抚了他们。他创造了一种局面，只要巴勒斯坦权力机构软弱，他就可以营造一种总体看法，即最好的办法就是吞并约旦河西岸。 We weakened the very institution that we could have worked with, and strengthened Hamas.”

;

;Golan was referring to a strategy of Netanyahu's, deployed over the past fourteen years, that is known as the “conception.”其目的是通过支持其敌人哈马斯来削弱寻求领土妥协的巴勒斯坦权力机构。虽然拒绝与巴勒斯坦权力机构及其领导人马哈茂德·阿巴斯进行任何严肃的谈判，但政府允许卡塔尔的数亿美元流入哈马斯的金库，并增加了在以色列境内工作的加沙人的工作许可流量。内塔尼亚胡并不是以某种方式关心加沙的穷人；而是因为内塔尼亚胡对加沙的贫困感到担忧。在他看来，这是一个战略诡计问题。 But, as Golan's old boss Gadi Eisenkot, a former IDF chief of staff, told ;Ma'ariv; last year, Netanyahu carried out this strategy “in total opposition to the national assessment of the National Security Council, which determined that there was a need to disconnect from the Palestinians and establish two states.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;One aspect of Netanyahu's Churchill complex is his colossal self-assurance, and he was unflinchingly confident in his “conception.”据报道，他在利库德集团会议上表示，“任何想要阻止巴勒斯坦国建立的人都必须支持支持哈马斯并向哈马斯转移资金。 。 。 。这是我们战略的一部分。”去年 12 月，他对沙特电视台的采访者说：“我认为我的记录不言而喻。我领导以色列的最后十年是以色列历史上最安全的十年。但不仅对以色列人来说是安全的，对巴勒斯坦人来说也是安全的。” It was a litany of bad faith, deception, and delusion, with disastrous consequences.

;

;“I commanded Judea and Samaria from 2005 to 2007,” Golan told me, referring to the West Bank. “最令我沮丧的是，没有人能够想象这两个民族如何共处。我们哪儿也不去。他们不会去任何地方。职业并不是解决问题的办法。我们两国人民都应该由明智的多数人领导，但两国人民都由各自的极端分子领导。 This is the challenge of Israel.”

;

;In the meantime, there was the spectre of a land war.戈兰认为，这是不可避免的：“为了恢复我们南部的村庄和基布兹，我们需要该地区百分百的安全。要做到这一点，你需要让哈马斯军队变得无关紧要。将会有持续不断的行动和攻击。 In the next few days, you will see only the first stage of that war.”

;

;Before he hurried off to his next appointment, I asked him about the prospects of a multifront war: with Hamas, in Gaza;与真主党在黎巴嫩边境；来自叙利亚和伊拉克的伊朗傀儡民兵；即使是伊朗本身。 He put the chances at “ten or fifteen per cent.”

;

;In school or beyond, nearly every Israeli encounters Hayim Nahman Bialik's 1904 poem “In the City of Killing,” written in Hebrew just after the pogrom in Kishinev, in the Russian Empire's Pale of Settlement.当地一家反犹太主义报纸发表报道称，犹太人在该地区谋杀了一名基督徒儿童，并用他的血来做逾越节的无酵饼，随后牧师带领的暴民发起了暴乱，高呼“杀掉犹太人！”敖德萨的一个历史委员会指派年轻的希伯来语教师比亚利克前往基希讷乌采访幸存者，了解一种口述历史。这首诗成为反对沙皇和俄罗斯帝国的战斗口号，并最终成为犹太人民族自豪感的口号。 Inspired by Bialik's words, many Russian Jews left for Europe, the United States, and Palestine.

;
;
;

;Get up and walk through the city of the massacre
;And with your hand touch and lock your eyes
;On the cooled brain and clots of blood
;Dried on tree trunks, rocks, and fences; it is they.
;Go to the ruins, to the gaping breaches.

;
;
;

;Forty-nine Jews were massacred by the mob in Kishinev.很难知道奥特夫阿扎一天内一千四百人被杀意味着什么。与帕莱地区的犹太人不同，以色列几乎没有防御能力。 But it is vulnerable, and it was plain that this massacre would influence the collective psyche—and the politics—of Israel for years to come.

;

;A week after the events of October 7th, an Israeli journalist and friend arranged for us to travel about an hour south from Tel Aviv to Kibbutz Kfar Aza.经过沿海城市阿什杜德和阿什凯隆后，我们转向东边，远离加沙，进入以色列国防军士兵重兵把守的地区。 In the fields near Gaza, troops, tanks, and armored personnel had started to establish positions for the planned ground invasion.

;
;
;

;An IDF press officer gave us bulletproof vests and Kevlar helmets.几天内没有发生交火，没有证据表明哈马斯武装分子仍留在该地区，但一名军官警告说，“这是一个活跃的场景。”卡法阿扎 (Kfar Aza) 成立于 1951 年，是一个繁荣的基布兹，现场有两家企业，一家生产塑料染料，另一家为活动提供照明和音响系统。那里住着大约七百五十人，还有幼儿园、健身房、游泳池和墓地。现在大部分房屋都成了弹痕累累的废墟，有的塌陷、有的被炸毁、有的被烧毁。当天早些时候，地面上的最后几具尸体已经被清理干净，但死亡的恶臭仍然挥之不去。 We were told there had been so many corpses, often burned or mutilated, that the young IDF soldiers could not bear the work and called in ;Zaka;, an organization of religious volunteers who, with meticulous care, collect bodies, body parts, and even blood, and give the dead a proper burial according to Jewish law.我看过一段视频，其中一名志愿者将冷水浇在一具被烧焦的尸体上。我问为什么。 To cool it off, I was told, so that when it is placed in a plastic collection bag the bag doesn't melt.

;;

;One of our guides was Golan Vach, a reserve colonel in the IDF's Home Front Command search-and-rescue unit.在漫长的职业生涯中，他曾在海地、巴西、菲律宾和佛罗里达州瑟夫赛德发生各种灾难后执行任务。今年二月，土耳其南部发生地震，造成四万五千多人死亡，瓦赫和他的团队从废墟中救出了十九人，并受到了总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安的嘉奖。瓦赫是一位四十多岁的老人，身体轻盈，意志坚定，带领我们挨家挨户地参观了一座废墟，讲述了当地安全人员、士兵和警察所进行的战斗，尽管他们的武器装备不足且人手不足，但还是冲到了卡法阿扎并营救了他们所遇到的任何人。直到陆军大军到来。 That took many agonizing hours, and, for long periods, the Hamas fighters were able to take their time, killing, burning, collecting hostages.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Vach led us into one ruin and described two women who'd been found there, both naked, their hands bound behind their backs, shot in the head.他说，他在其他地方发现了屠刀，一名被斩首的士兵。他指着地上的哈马斯装备碎片：一把烧焦的卡拉什尼科夫弹夹、一件废弃的战斗背心、一架滑翔伞。他已经习惯了关于他从房子里抱出来的死婴的问题。 “人们问我为什么不拍照，”他说。 “我说，‘对不起，我也有我的极限。’ ”

;

;Then, unprompted, he took out his phone and started showing me photographs he did take, one corpse after another. “等等，”他一边说，一边挥手。 “你会看到那堆东西。他们随身带着汽油。 Their intention was to burn.”

;

;In some parts of the world, I said, people will say it's all fake, it's all ;hasbara,; government propaganda.瓦赫一眨不眨地看着我。 “有人说大屠杀不存在，对吧？面对这样的人，你会如何应对？”他说。 “我有照片。但除非那些人亲眼所见，否则我猜他们不会相信。但这些人，如果他们亲眼所见，他们也会说我们伪造了情况。所以没关系。”他的肩膀垂了下来。他的双手拍在身体两侧，再次环顾周围的废墟。 “这是邪恶的。” In the near distance, from Gaza, we could hear rockets, Iron Dome interceptions, and Israeli jets.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Most of the evacuees from Kfar Aza were taken to a hotel on the grounds of Kibbutz Shefayim, on the Mediterranean coast, north of Tel Aviv. I arrived one afternoon to see yet another mass shiva—a sombre picnic taking place on the lawn, families huddled together, eating, carefully eying their kids kicking a soccer ball, playing tag.

;

;Inside, in a conference room off the lobby, a woman from Kfar Aza named Yael Felus had helped set up what she called a “war room.”那里有十几个人，用手机和笔记本电脑工作，安排精神科护理、组织葬礼巴士、分发衣服和食物。费卢斯在距离加沙约半英里的沿海城市斯德罗特长大。 “我需要一个更安静的地方，”她告诉我。 “所以我去了卡法阿扎。这似乎是一个抚养我的孩子的好地方。”现在，她说，只有“他们夷平加沙并搬到埃及去生活”，她才会回去。她知道这听起来如何，但似乎并不在意。她怎么能回去呢？在派我去见在大厅里闲逛的基布兹幸存者之前，她说：“我的大多数朋友都死了。” She tried to count them all on her fingers, then gave up.

;

;I met a woman named Roni Stahl Lupo, who was born at Kfar Aza in 1972;她几乎认识死在那里的所有人。她也无法给出准确的数字。她和她的丈夫有三个孩子，经营着一家设计工业厨房的小企业。她的妹妹齐夫·斯塔尔 (Ziv Stahl) 是人权组织 Yesh Din（有法律）的执行董事。她的家人勉强活着逃离了卡法阿扎。在她的女儿和男友逃离基布兹之前，哈马斯枪手向她们开枪，男友的手被击中两枪。 Lupo had lived through countless rocket attacks over the years, but now she was unsure whether she would stay in Israel at all.

;
;
;

;“During the demonstrations against this government, I began to feel that I'm no longer part of the majority of this country,” she said. “从道德上、社会上来说，这都不是我的以色列。我是左翼、阿什肯纳兹人、基布兹尼克、世俗人士，这不再是以色列的身份。我和这个国家的合同已经结束了。 It's broken.”

;

;She was both enraged at Hamas and deeply anxious about the bombing of Gaza and the ground incursion taking shape near her old home. “我一直在想，这些行动会因为我而发生，有人会因为我而被杀，”她说。 “And I cannot live with that.”

;

;One morning, I visited Sari Nusseibeh, in East Jerusalem.努塞贝是一位研究早期伊斯兰哲学的学者，曾担任亚西尔·阿拉法特的非正式顾问，出生于大马士革，住在谢赫贾拉赫，这是耶路撒冷的一个社区，多年来一直受到定居者和以色列政府的攻击和侵占。他的家族非常显赫。几个世纪以来，努赛贝家族一直是老城圣墓教堂的穆斯林守护者。努塞贝的父亲安瓦尔是耶路撒冷总督和安曼驻圣詹姆斯宫廷大使。努赛贝现年七十四岁，在巴勒斯坦公共生活中一直是一个明显温和的声音，他的朋友遍布学术界。他对巴勒斯坦权利的坚持毫不妥协，并且在他的书中，他对犹太历史和以色列的焦虑表示同情。 At the same time, his disapproval of violence—whether perpetrated by Israeli settlers or Palestinian suicide bombers—is absolute.

;

;Nusseibeh's weariness and apprehension as we sat down were palpable. “我们在技术、人工智能、医学以及除了人际关系之外的所有领域都取得了如此多的进步，”他说。 “我知道持续的爆炸会持续很多年，直到人们最终了解到必须有另一种方式，但不是像这样的对抗。”他耸耸肩。 “No matter what, we will end up where we started, with the Palestinians and the Israelis living here together and needing to find a proper formula.”

;

;On the morning of October 7th, Nusseibeh had just returned home from dropping off his wife and his daughter at the airport when he heard sirens. “我的第一反应是‘嗯，有趣。’这种情况时不时地发生，但随后警报声越来越多，然后是砰的一声，房子真的摇晃了。 I thought, This might be serious.”

;

;At first, he sensed great pride among many in his East Jerusalem community as the news broke.骑摩托车、皮卡车和悬挂式滑翔机的巴勒斯坦人做到了连外国军队都没有做到的事情。 1973年，埃及军队在西奈半岛西部出其不意地袭击了以色列，叙利亚则在戈兰高地消灭了以色列坦克，但他们大多没有靠近以色列人口中心。许多巴勒斯坦人最初庆祝哈马斯的袭击，认为这是对以色列无懈可击的感觉的打击。但随后，努塞贝说，随着暴行的证据成为众所周知，这种喜悦就凝固了。 Some even spoke of the incursion as a conspiracy, a guarantee that Israel would now turn so far to the right that the Palestinians would ;never; get statehood.这些图像令人震惊。令努塞贝震惊的一个细节更为平庸：普通加沙人尾随武装恐怖分子进入以色列并进行抢劫。在一个视频中，我看到一个加沙人拿着偷来的吉他平静地行走；其他人则拿走平板电视并带回加沙。 “这就像中世纪的战争，”努塞贝说。 “People come behind the fighting to steal.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;He despairs at the spectacle of bloodlust, the ecstasies of killing.但他也相信，如果没有政治解决方案，哈马斯和暴力极端主义总体上不会消退。 “认为哈马斯是外星人是错误的——它是国家挂毯的一部分，”他说。 “它会根据其他因素变大或变小。你可以消灭现在操纵哈马斯的人，但你不能完全消灭它。只要巴以冲突存在，它就会作为一种思维方式、一种想法继续存在。”他接着说，“人们说，哈马斯在西岸的支持比在加沙更多，而加沙的情况恰恰相反，巴勒斯坦权力机构得到的支持更多，这与治理有关。”事实上，10 月 7 日袭击发生前不久进行的一项调查显示，加沙人对哈马斯普遍不满。这两个实体都充斥着腐败，而且缺乏基本能力。最重要的是，他们受到占领和围困的影响。 The PA was no more capable of taking care of the needs of Ramallah and Jenin, Nusseibeh argued, than Hamas was able to cope with the burdens of daily life in Rafah, Khan Yunis, and Gaza City.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Before we went our separate ways, Nusseibeh said he thought that Arab rulers, despite it all, had no taste for a multifront war, one that might pull in the United States.现在还不是世纪中叶，当时许多阿拉伯领导人仍然认为以色列是暂时的。但他并不乐观——至少在短期内是这样。 “我认为人们都疯了，”他告诉我。 “尤其是处于权力地位的人。 They are crazier than the average person and can easily lead populations to war.”

;

;On August 10, 2006, three Israeli novelists—David Grossman, Amos Oz, and AB Yehoshua—called on the Israeli government to accept a ceasefire proposal to end the Second Lebanon War.两天后，格罗斯曼的儿子乌里，一名二十岁的以色列坦克旅上士，在与真主党的战斗中阵亡。格罗斯曼成年后的大部分时间都是一名和平活动家，他在示威中发表演讲，发表文章，时而激烈，时而深情，旨在刺穿同胞的冷漠。 1987 年出版的《黄风》是一本关于占领的报道文章集（其中一些发表在这些页面上），令以色列读者感到震惊。当这种情况并不常见时，格罗斯曼参观了约旦河西岸的难民营和教室。在报道纳布卢斯以色列军事法庭针对巴勒斯坦人的诉讼时，格罗斯曼引用了《射杀大象》一文，其中乔治·奥威尔描述了缅甸的一名帝国警察，“他戴着面具，他的脸长得适合面具” ”。两位作家的主题是共同的：在实施不公正的过程中，殖民者欺骗并毁灭了自己。 2008 年出版的小说《天涯海角》是他的代表作，讲述了格罗斯曼失去儿子的故事。 I asked Grossman, who lives in Mevaseret Zion, in the hills outside Jerusalem, about his reaction to the events of October 7th.

;

;“Of course, we felt something was wrong with the whole management of the country,” he said. “我们觉得我们的总理把所有的时间都投入到了审判中，没有足够的时间来照顾国家。 But no one could anticipate ;this;.”他继续说道：“我们看到了一个可能导致哈马斯接管特拉维夫的过程。我们不想考虑灾难，但思考灾难是我的职业，我们非常接近这一点。我坦白地告诉你，当我面对这样的邪恶，纯粹的邪恶时，我不想生活在这样一个允许这样的怪物存在的世界里。仅仅接触这些事情，看到儿童、妇女、孕妇、婴儿被谋杀——就不可能吸收它。五十六年的占领是可怕的。我一生都在写作和反对它，我看到美国大学和其他地方的一些朋友试图实现某种平衡。但罪恶总是不能相提并论。有时，我告诉我的朋友，客观是掩盖怯懦的好方法，可以说“我们很糟糕，他们也很糟糕。” By doing so, you spare yourself, you refuse to expose yourself to the atrocities in front of you.”

;;

;We spoke of the Palestinians who argued that they had been forgotten. “首先，他们是对的，”格罗斯曼说。 “And yet there is something in the ;joy; of killing, it just feels different. 2005年我们撤离时，哈马斯犯了一个重大错误。大约一万名定居者被背井离乡。如果我们撤军后，巴勒斯坦人开始利用他们所承诺的财政支持在加沙进行建设，如果他们使加沙成为如何重新建立生活的一个测试案例，如果加沙已经成为（如果不是“新加坡”）如果中东至少是一个可以发展生命的地方，那么下一次撤军就会很快到来。相反，他们选择了另一条路。接下来的两年里，有数千枚导弹从加沙瞄准我们。 And now, after they have done this, you start to think, Well, if you have such a neighbor, you had better be well equipped and suspicious all the time.”

;
;
;

;In his view, the prospects for Israel, which just celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary of existence, were grave. “我认为现在作为以色列人的任务将更加艰巨，”他说。 “保护这个国家的需要将是一个更加严重的问题。在与多个阿拉伯国家签署协议和《亚伯拉罕协议》后，我们认为这一切都已经过去了。但你不能在签署《亚伯拉罕协议》的同时忽视巴勒斯坦人。现在我们将看到，作为一个以色列人，时刻警惕意外和暴力是多么令人疲惫不堪。再一次，我们必须既是雅典又是斯巴达。 We will try to be tolerant and decent to our neighbors, not racist but pluralist, liberal, yet at the same time very tough militarily.”

;

;In reality, Grossman knew, the political temper of the country was likely to grow increasingly distant from his view of the world. “我猜以色列会变得越来越右翼，越来越宗教化，”他继续说道。 “犹太人的身份将被缩小到自卫。尽管陆军失败了，但人们对陆军的崇拜将会越来越多。我向我的总理大声疾呼：以色列这个宝贵的东西掌握在你手中。你对这个独特的国家负有责任。 If this country fails, will history be generous again?”

;

;Sam Bahour is an American-born Palestinian who moved from Ohio to the West Bank in the wake of the Oslo Accords, a generation ago.他认为自己正在建设一个未来的国家，因此帮助建立了巴勒斯坦电信公司，经常往返于约旦河西岸和加沙地带之间。他住在他父亲来自的约旦河西岸小镇贝拉赫，当我们交谈时，他对定居者的骚扰和暴力以及看似随机逮捕巴勒斯坦人的迅速增加感到愤怒。 “我们每天早上打开收音机，但听不到天气情况，”他说。 “我们听说有人被捕。” Even more alarming, there were reports that dozens of Palestinians in the West Bank had been killed since the Hamas attack, some by settlers.

;

;For Bahour, there was nothing utopian about demanding a political solution;只是它的否认是不切实际的，也是不公正的。 “我们不求月亮，”他说。 “我们要求结束长达五十六年的军事占领。我担心的是，这一轮谈判不仅给加沙和加沙人民造成了巨大的物质损害，同时也暴露了西方和国际社会的虚伪。 And, if we go on doing that, it's a free-for-all.”

;

;In the West Bank and elsewhere, Bahour told me, “all the attention now is focussed on stopping the bombing in a small, intensely overcrowded place that is fifty per cent children.整个民用基础设施正在被拆除。我不知道任何人——以色列人、犹太裔美国人或任何人——如何认为这次袭击会让以色列更安全。他们的做法恰恰相反。具有讽刺意味的是，哈马斯所做的事情可能会起到拯救内塔尼亚胡、让他继续掌权的作用。每个人都知道，这场战争停止的那一天，他将离开政府。所以现在他是一个没有什么可失去的人，就像加沙人民一样。 And people with nothing to lose lash out.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The scenes of Hamas fighters standing in triumph over the dead, taking selfies and shouting “;Allahu akbar!;,” recalled, for some, Frantz Fanon's line that “the colonized is the persecuted person who is always dreaming of becoming the persecutor.”现在，这些场景正在被满目疮痍的加沙场景所取代。与努塞贝和格罗斯曼一样，巴胡尔明确反对杀害平民。与此同时，他说，“我们必须明智，足够明智，能够在头脑中容纳多种想法。有人认为加沙人会冲破围栏，冲出他们的露天监狱——这是一回事。但他们进入村庄并以他们的方式杀害平民则是另一回事。这是一种可怕的行为，必须受到谴责。 But I also can't just have a knee-jerk reaction and think this is a story that started October 7th.”

;

;The task of holding in one's head multiple thoughts—multiple facts—was nearly impossible, particularly in the face of sloganeering and the allure of militancy.有人认为，在内塔尼亚胡政府部长的怂恿下，以色列定居者（其中许多人持有武器）加剧了针对巴勒斯坦村民的日常暴力行为。尽管以色列装备精良，拥有强大的盟友，但它的面积也只有新泽西州那么大，而且面临着多个敌人——哈马斯、真主党和伊朗——这些国家的领导人经常谈到消灭“犹太复国主义实体”。加沙的失业率高达百分之四十五，水几乎无法饮用，电力和食品供应短缺，医疗保健系统一片废墟。反犹太主义的广度、强度和暴力再次增长。这种对巴勒斯坦人的蔑视实际上是以色列现政府的常态，正如财政部长斯莫特里奇在法国的追悼会上发表讲话时，他站在一张将加沙、约旦河西岸和约旦融为一体的地图前一样。以色列宣称，“不存在巴勒斯坦历史”，或者当国家安全部长本-格维尔告诉记者时，“我、我的妻子、我的孩子们在犹太和撒马利亚的道路上漫步的权利比这更重要”。阿拉伯人的行动权。”数千名巴勒斯坦人在最近的空袭中丧生，超过一百万人在国内流离失所。 There will be no end to it anytime soon: the funerals, the recriminations, the threats, the fear, the assaults.

;

;There was also the grim fact that Hamas had, in the most brutal fashion, shattered the illusion that a state could provide Israelis the guarantee of security.正如第 12 频道的新闻主播约尼特·莱维 (Yonit Levi) 对我所说的那样，“犹太人的每一个噩梦都成真了。”那么会得到什么回报呢？每晚对加沙的空袭都以前所未有的速度进行——致命且持续——地面入侵可能会导致城市战争的地狱景象，另一个费卢杰。 It was a familiar nightmare, reminiscent of what followed 9/11, in which a stronger nation pursues a policy that, while trying to defeat an enemy for carrying out an unspeakable massacre, kills countless civilians and ultimately inflicts untold and lasting damage on itself.

;

;The day after my visit to Kfar Aza, I took a cab to the town of Gan Yavne, twenty miles from Gaza, to attend the funeral of all five members of the Kutz family.利夫纳特和阿维夫·库茨被发现与他们的孩子罗特姆、约纳坦和伊夫塔赫一起死在床上。在整个以色列，每个人似乎都知道这个故事，他们是在一种最后的家庭拥抱中被发现的。很少有人知道，据报道，在墙外的汗尤尼斯，巴希提家族的九名成员在空袭中丧生。 Killing was the common condition.

;

;At Gan Yavne, mourners stared at the five graves, deep and sharply dug. As people gathered under and around the perimeter of a white tent that blocked the hard afternoon sun, a volunteer from ;Zaka;, a man of astonishing industry and fitness, kept hopping in and out of the graves, preparing them, lining up sacks of dirt, ordering things according to Jewish law.我奋力向前，想离服务更近一点，发现了米娅·克劳斯 (Mia Kraus)，她是一名青少年，也是卡法阿扎 (Kfar Aza) 的撤离者，我曾在谢法伊姆基布兹 (Kibbutz Shefayim) 与她交谈过。我重新介绍了自己。 “我记得你。”她害羞地说。 Like everyone at Kfar Aza, she knew the Kutz family well.

;
;
;

;More teen-agers from the kibbutz squeezed past the surrounding headstones and gathered tightly together, arm in arm with Mia in the first row behind the family's relatives. Her mind was here and ;there:; one of her friends was kidnapped and later found dead.我记得米娅十六岁，与诗人莫萨布·阿布·托哈差点在加沙街头被杀时的年龄相同。 In Mosab's poem “The Wounds,” he writes:

;
;
;

;If, when the rocket fell, I had moved my head a bit
;to watch a bird on a tree or to count
;the clouds coming from the west side,
;the shrapnel might have cut through my throat.
;I wouldn't be married to my wife,
;father of three kids, one born in America. 。 。 .
;I look around me, relatives circle my bed.
;I watch them as they chat. I imagine them praying round my coffin.

;
;
;

;The funeral service began.当米娅和我在谢法伊姆基布兹谈话时，她告诉我，她不能再待在一个关着门的房间里，甚至浴室也不行。这让我回想起在她家躲了二十个小时，哈马斯枪手就在她门外的情景。透过半开的窗户，她可以听到他们的谈话。不知何故，枪手从未进来。她的家人幸存下来。 Yet she regularly found herself overtaken by crippling waves of fear.

;

;The coffins were carried in and the names were read: one by one by one by one by one. At first, there was silence, but now a great communal lamentation convulsed the assembled. I have never heard such weeping as I did that afternoon. There would be many more funerals to come, many more convulsions of grief. But the sounds of lamentation never carry as far as those of rockets, missiles, artillery, bombs. As I was finishing this piece, Mosab messaged me, describing the nightly bombings in his neighborhood. A ground assault was imminent. “Any moment I may not be in this world,” he said. ♦

;Late in the summer, several hundred autoworkers jammed into the auditorium of United Auto Workers Local 12, in Toledo, Ohio, for a monthly meeting. Local 12 是该国最大的联合工会，代表一万多人，其中包括镇上一家吉普车工厂的近六千人。通常情况下，每月一次的会议吸引的人数要少得多，但美国汽车工人联合会成员中一直流传着可能举行罢工的消息。工会的合同定于三周后午夜到期，工会与三巨头——通用汽车、福特和 Stellantis（克莱斯勒和吉普车的母公司）代表之间的谈判毫无进展。布鲁斯·鲍姆豪威尔 (Bruce Baumhower) 现年 68 岁，担任当地总统已有三十多年，他走上讲台。他有一缕红灰色的头发，有着前流水线工人的粗大前臂。他描述了不久前工会如何放弃来之不易的工资和福利，以帮助拯救危机时期的行业。他说，这些妥协被企业的贪婪所利用。接近三分之一的单位每小时的收入仍然低于十六美元。十四年来，起薪几乎没有变化。 “现在一切都将改变，”鲍姆豪威尔说。 “Now it's our time!”

;

;The crowd exploded, applauding and yelling.迈克·萨瓦亚 (Mike Sawaya) 靠在讲台后面的墙上，他的家族已经在这家工厂工作了三代。当他在同一个礼堂第一次见到鲍姆豪威尔时，他才八岁。他太紧张了，以至于把两盘辣椒通心粉洒到了腿上。 “布鲁斯让它撕裂，”萨瓦亚说。 “这就是他出名的原因。” Baumhower told me later, in his office, “It probably wasn't a very professional speech—I just said the scam's up.”

;

;On September 14th, the UAW's new president, Shawn Fain, called the first simultaneous strike against all Big Three companies in the union's history.他采取了一种新策略——“站立罢工”——最初要求每家公司只罢工一个装配厂。这个名字是指十九世纪三十年代的静坐罢工，当时工人们占领工厂，阻止管理层或破坏罢工的人操作机器。 The stand-up tactic, as opposed to walking out all at once, would allow the UAW to stretch its eight-hundred-and-twenty-five-million-dollar strike fund, so that the strike could go longer and wider if progress wasn't made.

;

;Baumhower, who started at Jeep in 1972, told me that he was pleased his plant was one of the first. “We ;wanted; to be the target,” he said. “我们认为车间里存在着最不公正的现象。”他说，该工厂的“补充”或临时兼职员工比例是全国最高的之一，其中一些人已经以这种方式工作了五六年，没有保证获得全职工作。说。一名会员的儿子最近来找鲍姆豪威尔寻求工作。鲍姆豪威尔向他保证，这不会有问题——公司需要一百多名新员工。 “孩子问，‘是啊，多少钱？’ “鲍姆豪威尔回忆道。 “我说，‘十五点七十八分。’他说：“哦。”我说：“怎么了？”他说：“我在 Arby's 工作，卖薯条，售价 17 美元。”那么我可以把十五岁的汽车的变速箱放进去，或者把十七岁的薯条放进篮子里吗？他还在阿比家。 Pretty smart kid.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The 2007-08 financial crisis was followed by a government bailout and a supervised restructuring of Chrysler and GM, which forced UAW workers across the Big Three to make major concessions to keep their jobs—and to keep the companies solvent.每年的生活费用调整和退休人员的健康保险都消失了，其中许多人还没有达到享受医疗保险的年龄。甚至休息时间也从六分钟减少到五分钟。最重要的是引入了两级薪酬制度，新员工的起薪是现有员工的一半。 New hires also would not receive a pension.

;

;Since the crash, average hourly wages for workers in vehicle manufacturing, adjusted for inflation, have fallen by nearly twenty per cent, according to a recent study by the Economic Policy Institute.与此同时，汽车制造商也取得了巨大的财务成功。到 2013 年，财政部出售了其在克莱斯勒和通用汽车的最后股份，并取消了对高管薪酬的限制。过去十年，三巨头的利润几乎翻了一番。这些公司斥资数十亿美元回购股票，首席执行官的薪酬上涨了 40%； Mary Barra, the CEO of GM, earned twenty-nine million dollars last year.

;
;
;

;The Big Three aren't a monolith.上周三，被誉为与工人关系最好的福特公司达成了一项临时协议，以结束工厂的罢工。 The terms included a twenty-five-per-cent raise over a four-and-a-half-year contract, an end to wage tiers, and a right-to-strike provision over plant closures, a first for the UAW An agreement with one company generally pressures the other two to settle along similar lines.

;

;The strike comes amid a wider revival of labor.尽管工会成员数量处于历史最低水平，但过去几年罢工工人的数量已达到数十年来的最高水平。 Recent walkouts by members of ;SAG;-;AFTRA; and the Writers Guild and by workers at Kaiser Permanente have enjoyed broad public approval.盖洛普民意调查显示，现在有 67% 的美国人支持工会，比 2009 年高出 19 个百分点。此外，民意调查显示，75% 的人支持美国汽车工人联合会与汽车公司的斗争。尽管如此，仍然存在一些反感情绪。 Jim Cramer, an analyst at CNBC, implied that Fain was a Trotskyite and encouraged the auto companies to move their entire production process to Mexico.

;

;Recently, at Baumhower's striking Jeep plant, a group of workers from the Wrangler paint line were marching in front of one of the main entrances of the three-and-a-half-million-square-foot complex.气氛很挑衅。他们高呼：“没有正义，就没有吉普车！”当 75 号州际公路上的司机鸣笛呼啸而过时，他大声喊道。早些时候，有人将一份旧的 UAW 合同副本放入燃烧桶中焚烧。值班的罢工队长托德·吉布森 (Todd Gibson) 让工人们来回行走了六个小时。 Semi trucks were still making deliveries to the plant, slowly nosing forward through the picket.

;

;“Thirty-eight years in jail,” Gibson said with a laugh, when I asked how long he'd worked at the plant. “并不是每个人都适合成为工厂工人。你必须能够处理长期、重复的性质，让你的思绪转移到不同的地方。”这是他任职期间该厂首次罢工。发生了什么变化？他指着艾米·乔·卢特克（Amy Jo Luedtke），一位有着漂白金发的中年妇女。 Luedtke 上小学时，她决定有一天要去工厂工作，当时她开着朋友父母的“裸”吉普车（没有门，没有车顶）。作为一名补充工，她已经在油漆线上工作了四年。 “我在这里做着他们正在做的同样的事情，”她说，看了一眼她的同事。 “我应该得到他们得到的同样的东西。”吉布森告诉我，“看，我的演出快结束了，对吧？这些家伙才刚刚开始。 I want to make it ;good; for them.”

;

;On Halloween night, 2021, Jennifer Fultz went trick-or-treating with her seven-year-old daughter, Aria, and her ten-year-old son, Jordan, in her home town of Rockford, Illinois.孩子们都打扮成皮卡丘。富尔茨有着长长的栗色头发、淡褐色的眼睛和厚厚的眼镜，他不得不提前结束比赛。她把孩子们带回家，拥抱并亲吻他们告别，收拾好车，然后与母亲和两只猫一起，开始了前往托莱多的六个小时的车程。第二天，她开始在吉普车工厂开始新的工作。尽管孩子们很快就会加入她的行列，但她还是感到紧张和伤心。 “我担心，如果出了什么问题，只有我和我妈妈在一个全新的城市，”她说。 “I was praying to God that I had made the right decision.”

;
;
;

;For years, Fultz had worked at a Stellantis plant outside Rockford, building Jeep Cherokees.该公司一波又一波地裁员，然后工厂完全闲置，剩下的 1300 个工作岗位被裁掉。据报道，切诺基的下一条生产线将在墨西哥托卢卡建造，使该工厂成为北美自由贸易协定的又一个受害者。 Since ;NAFTA; went into effect, in 1994, it has cost the United States nearly a million jobs, a significant percentage of them in vehicle and parts manufacturing, according to a study by Robert Scott, a recently retired economist at the Economic Policy Institute. ;NAFTA; paved the way for other similar agreements, most notably one that established permanent normal trade relations with China, facilitating its entry into the World Trade Organization, in 2001. Scott estimates that the ensuing trade deficit cost the United States nearly four million jobs, most of them in manufacturing, which tended to be more heavily unionized than other industries.就连外包的幽灵也为企业提供了强有力的棍棒：据 UAW 的一位首席谈判代表称，Stellantis 最近威胁要将其 Ram 1500 的生产也转移到墨西哥。 (In a statement, Stellantis said, “We are not commenting on production sites for future products.”)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In the past twenty years, the Big Three have closed more than sixty American plants.富尔茨告诉我，她以前的工厂是来自纽约、马里兰州和密苏里州关闭工厂的汽车工人的“大熔炉”。在受雇于 Stellantis 之前，她曾在其他三份工作中工作过——在 Kohl's、Papa John's 和 Subway 担任主管——但仍然无法搬出母亲的房子。 “国内没有很多好工作，”她说。 “Once Stellantis pulled the plug, that was it for the whole community.”

;

;Fultz works ten-hour shifts, six or seven days a week.长时间的工作对她的身体健康造成了损害。她说，她的肩膀上住着一个“小妖精”。 （富尔茨在车身修理厂工作了一年半，在那里她整天举起和拉动沉重的零件。）“我不能抱着我轻如羽毛的女儿超过五秒钟，因为我的手麻木了，”她告诉我。去年，她的母亲被诊断出患有肺癌。富尔茨负责照顾她，但她母亲的其他家人和朋友都离她那么远，她感到内疚。 “I know that my family is suffering because I brought them here,” Fultz told me, as tears started to stream down her face.

;;

;Her career in the auto industry has been marked by a sense of delayed recompense for the bailout concessions. “我们被承诺，子孙后代将能够拿回所放弃的东西，”她说。 “但那从未发生过。我没有养老金。我退休后没有医疗保险。我已经三十三岁了，身体已经垮了。那不是美国梦。美国梦不是每周在工厂工作六十、七十个小时，让亿万富翁赚更多的钱，而我却忽略了和孩子们在一起的时间，和我母亲在一起的时间，和我先生在一起的时间——只是时间。 Then for the billionaires to say, 'You're being greedy'—am I?”

;
;
;

;In late September, President Joe Biden announced that he would visit a picket line in Michigan.富尔茨在那里遇见了他。 “我们碰了拳头，”她回忆道。 “我告诉他，‘拜登先生，请把工作留在美国。’”他的回答是“这就是我们需要电动汽车的原因”。拜登希望到 2032 年电动汽车将占国内乘用车市场的三分之二。他还宣布打算成为“美国历史上最支持工会的总统” ”。 The UAW's strike, in part, aims to push him to fulfill both promises, to enact what the union calls a “just transition.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The Biden Administration has called for tens of billions of dollars to support electric-vehicle manufacturing.各种联邦法律和计划都制定了激励措施，鼓励公司在美国生产电动汽车及其电池，并为这些工厂配备工会工人。 （去年通过的众议院版本的《通货膨胀削减法案》包括对购买工会制造的电动汽车提供四千五百美元的税收抵免，但在乔·曼钦的要求下，参议院版本中取消了该法案。）我们的税款将为这一转变提供资金，那么劳动力就不能落后，”费恩最近在“面对国家”节目中说道。一些著名的民主党人和政治评论家却提出了不同的看法。 “If climate change is a central problem, we should want climate-change technologies produced as inexpensively as possible,” Lawrence Summers, the Treasury Secretary under Bill Clinton, said last month.

;

;In 2022, GM partnered with a Korean electronics company to form a new venture called Ultium Cells, which opened a non-union battery plant behind a shuttered assembly complex in Lordstown, Ohio.这些公司获得了二十五亿美元的低息联邦贷款。但 Ultium 的起薪仅为每小时 16.50 美元。 （九月份，涨到了二十美元。）到目前为止，工厂已有一名工人因受伤死亡。其他人则因触电和可能接触化学品而入院治疗；也有报道称出现头晕、恶心、呕吐和烧伤。 (A technician had to be wheeled out on a gurney after being “sprayed in the face with toxic electrolyte.”)

;

;In December, workers at the plant voted overwhelmingly to unionize, but have so far been unable to secure a contract. According to a UAW safety report, there were twenty-two injuries reported to ;OSHA; in the first five months of 2023. A few weeks ago, federal regulators announced their intention to fine the company nearly three hundred thousand dollars. “这是一个危险的设施，比洛兹敦危险得多，”在旧建筑装配线上工作的 UAW 地区主任戴夫·格林 (Dave Green) 说。 The UAW found a fifty-per-cent-higher incidence of ;OSHA; violations there than in traditional GM plants. (A spokesperson for Ultium said, “All safety concerns are taken seriously, investigated, and addressed promptly.”)

;

;Last year, Jim Farley, Ford's CEO, predicted that fewer workers will be needed to manufacture electric vehicles, given that their power trains don't require engines and thus have significantly fewer moving parts.其他专家不同意。例如，卡内基梅隆大学研究人员去年的一项研究估计，生产电动汽车在短期和中期内实际上需要更多的就业机会，因为必要的组件制造起来更加复杂，即使数量较少。无论如何，大多数新宣布的电池工厂将建在对劳动力不利的南部各州。 6月，联邦政府向福特及其合作伙伴公司提供了90亿美元的贷款，用于在肯塔基州和田纳西州建造三个电池厂。 Fain criticized the Biden Administration for failing to pressure the companies to commit to using union labor.

;

;Fultz and I walked out to the parking lot of Local 12, so she could show me her bright-blue Wrangler.与该停车场中其他几辆吉普车的仪表板一样，它的仪表盘上排列着玩具鸭子，这是吉普车车主们互相赠送的善意象征，这种做法被称为“吉普车鸭子”。 “我对斯特兰蒂斯是又爱又恨，”富尔茨说。 “我需要他们保持经济上的成功。但即使他们今天关门——我希望他们永远不会关门——我也可能会去通用汽车或福特。 As crazy and unstable as the automobile industry is, there's something about knowing that a family is sitting in a car I could have built.”

;

;The day after Biden's visit to the Michigan picket line, Donald Trump showed up at Drake Enterprises, a non-union automotive-parts manufacturer in Macomb County, forty miles away.一排巨大的架子前面设立了一个讲台，架子上堆满了变速杆和其他传动部件。特勤局官员与戴着黑手套、穿着橄榄绿衬衫、满身纹身、留着胡须的男子分担安全责任。 Campaign volunteers passed out signs that read “;Union Members for Trump;” to anyone who would take them.

;

;Tony Brouckaert, a self-employed tool-and-die maker, was standing by himself in the crowded room.他曾经在一家液压工具厂工作，该厂有工会。他曾试图摆脱它。 “我坚信，如果你是一名勤奋的员工，你就不需要工会，”他告诉我。然而，他的大部分政治不满都是经济方面的，根源在于工会曾经可靠提供的福利消失了。 His job has left him with a bad shoulder, but Obamacare is too expensive, so he is waiting until he's sixty-five and on Medicare to have it treated.

;

;After several hours, Trump entered to Lee Greenwood's “God Bless the USA” and an ecstatic standing ovation.他的讲话时而流畅，时而具有欺骗性，时而令人恐惧，呼吁“经济民族主义的复兴”，并引发了日益严重的经济焦虑。他说：“我赌上一切来为你而战。” “我冒着一切风险来保护工人阶级免受腐败政治阶级的侵害。” He fixated on ;NAFTA;, a persistent theme of his campaigns, especially during stops in Rust Belt states, whose political swings have determined the winners of the past two Presidential elections. Trump called ;NAFTA; “the worst trade deal ever made” and boasted about having renegotiated it in 2018. (The new deal preserved much of the original one; it has been called ;NAFTA; 2.0.) He repeatedly emphasized the threat of electric vehicles. “对于汽车工人来说，拜登的被迫过渡是向地狱的过渡，”他说。 “这是向失业的过渡。”他补充说，目前的罢工毫无意义，因为“在拜登的授权下，整个汽车行业将被打包运往中国。” Though not many UAW members were present, he implored the crowd to lobby Shawn Fain to endorse him.

;In 2016, exit polls showed that Trump won two-thirds of voters who believe trade with foreign countries takes away American jobs;这帮助他击败了威斯康星州、密歇根州和宾夕法尼亚州，而他在这三个州的总票数还不到八万票。富尔茨告诉我，她觉得自己“在特朗普执政期间拥有最有保障的工作”。但特朗普的政治生涯一直以对劳工的强烈敌意为标志。 In 2015, when campaigning for President, he told the Detroit ;News; that automakers should pursue a kind of intra-national ;NAFTA;, moving plants out of Michigan to parts of the US where labor was cheaper, and then returning to the state after workers there had become desperate enough to accept lower wages. “你可以去美国的不同地方，然后最终你会绕一圈，”他说。 “We can do the rotation in the United States—it doesn't have to be in Mexico.”

;During Trump's Presidency, the country lost a hundred and seventy thousand manufacturing jobs and close to seven thousand factories. 2017年，特朗普任命管理方律师彼得·罗伯(Peter Robb)担任国家劳工关系委员会总法律顾问。 Robb had served as Ronald Reagan's lead attorney when Reagan fired more than eleven thousand air-traffic controllers, effectively breaking their union and igniting a decades-long attack on labor by the right.

;
;
;

;When Trump finished his speech, it was pouring outside.以赛亚·戈达德 (Isaiah Goddard) 站在雨中，等待向车队挥手，他是美国汽车工人联合会 (UAW) 成员，在福特零部件厂工作。 “我认为这是一次非常美丽的演讲，发自内心，”他说。 “这表明他关心我们汽车工人。” Goddard was eager to take up Trump's challenge: “I'm going to do everything I can to talk to Shawn Fain and try to get him to endorse Donald Trump.”

;

;Two days later, a “solidarity convoy” of Broncos, Jeeps, and Colorados gathered in the parking lot of Local 51, on Detroit's East Side.游行队伍向市中心驶去，鸣笛以示赞同：一名黑人沿着去工业化的主干道行走，举起了拳头；在托尼印第安村，两名白人慢跑者停下来鼓掌。工会成员已经在团结之家的停车场集合，这里是车队的目的地，也是美国汽车工人联合会的总部。这座低矮的现代主义建筑建于 1951 年，坐落在底特律河畔的一处场地上，这里曾经是埃德塞尔·福特的豪宅、果园、和花园。 Loudspeakers in the parking lot blasted DJ Khaled's “All I Do Is Win” as a group of workers began dancing wildly.

;

;Fain grabbed a microphone and jumped onto the bed of a Ram pickup.他留着灰色的短发，戴着眼镜。他看起来有点像高中商店老师。他首先慢吞吞地讲述了美国汽车工人联合会前主席沃尔特·鲁瑟 (Walter Reuther) 提出的一项计划，该计划旨在利用底特律汽车工厂的过剩产能在第二次世界大战期间生产军事装备，从而创造出后来被称为“军事装备”的产品。 “民主武器库”。该计划的要素被富兰克林·罗斯福采纳，将底特律变成了无与伦比的工业强国。克莱斯勒一家工厂生产了全国一半的坦克。 “八十年后，我们发现自己再次成为民主武库的一部分，”费恩说。 “这次不一样了。敌人不是大洋彼岸的外国势力。 The enemy is right here among us—it's corporate greed.”

;

;Fain, who is fifty-four, was raised in Kokomo, Indiana, a city of sixty thousand.科科莫拥有五个 Stellantis 动力总成工厂，总共雇用了 7000 多名员工。费恩的母亲是一名护士；他的父亲是该镇的警察局长。 “我的父母教导我：永远不要忘记你来自哪里，无论你去哪里或做什么，”他告诉我。 “We came from destitution.”

;;

;All four of Fain's grandparents worked at Kokomo auto plants.他们是在大萧条时期在田纳西州和肯塔基州的极度贫困中长大的。一位祖母和她的兄弟姐妹被遗弃在孤儿院。 Fain 的祖父于 1937 年受雇于克莱斯勒，同年 UAW 成立了“他对这份工作感到非常自豪，”Fain 说。在接下来的三十五年里，他的祖父保存了他的每一张工资单。 “他把它们放在盒子里直到他去世的那一天，”费恩继续说道。 “在他去世之前，他问他的孙子们我们是否想要什么。”费恩要了存根。 “老实说，我什至不知道为什么，”他说。 “But those have become a treasure to me.”

;

;In 1994, Fain was hired by Chrysler as an electrician.像许多汽车工人一样，他带着敬畏和恐惧回忆起第一天的经历。 “他们把我们带到了车间，”他说。 “我工作的压铸厂夏天很热，可达一百三十度。”高架起重机通过单轨运输熔融铝。警报器不断响起。 “我想，我到底把自己带入了什么境地？” he told me.

;

;Two years earlier, Fain had voted for Ross Perot over Bill Clinton and George H. W. Bush in the Presidential election. “非常简单，”佩罗在当年的一场辩论中说道。 “如果你为工厂工人支付每小时 12 美元、13 美元、14 美元的工资，并且你可以将工厂搬到边境以南，那么每小时支付 1 美元的劳动力…… 。 。没有环境控制，没有污染控制，没有退休金，你除了赚钱什么都不关心，就会有巨大的吸吮声音向南走。” “这引起了我的共鸣，”费恩说。 “He was the only candidate saying that.”
